clipboard_set_text.description: This function will set the clipboard to hold the defined string. You can set it to an empty string "" to effectively clear the clipboard of text.

cloud_file_save.name: cloud_file_save

parameters.description: The file to be uploaded (as a string).
A brief description of the data being stored.

cloud_file_save.description: This function will commit a file to the chosen cloud service for storage. The function will return a unique **id** value that should then be used in the appropriate asynchronous event to identify the DS map that is returned as a "call back" from the cloud service. The file should contain *all* the information that you need to save for your game as you can only store one single "data blob" to the cloud, and running this function again will overwrite any previously stored values (as will using the `cloud_string_save()` function). The description should be a short string of information that describes the save, eg: "Level2, Stage2".

cloud_string_save.name: cloud_string_save

parameters.description: The data string to be uploaded.
A brief description of the data being stored.

cloud_string_save.description: This function will commit a string to the chosen cloud service for storage. The function will return a unique **id** value that should then be used in the appropriate asynchronous event to identify the DS map that is returned as a "call back" from the cloud service. The string should contain *all* the information that you need to save for your game as you can only store one single "data blob" to the cloud, and running this function again will overwrite any previously stored values (as will using the `cloud_file_save()` function). The description should be a short string of information that describes the save, eg: "Level2, Stage2".

cloud_synchronise.name: cloud_synchronise
cloud_synchronise.description: This function would normally be called at the start of a new game and is used to retrieve the current status of the cloud service at game start up. The function returns a unique **id** value which would then be used in the  [Asynchronous Cloud Event](https://manual.yoyogames.com/The_Asset_Editors/Object_Properties/Async_Events/Cloud.htm) to retrieve the relevant information from the DS map that is created.

code_is_compiled.name: code_is_compiled
code_is_compiled.description: This function will return `true` if the platform compiles outside of the virtual machine, such as for the YYC and JS platforms.

collision_circle.name: collision_circle

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the center of the circle to check.
The y coordinate of the center of the circle to check.
The radius (distance in pixels from its center to its edge).
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on pixel-perfect collisions (true = slow) or its bounding box in general (false = fast).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (`true`) or not (`false`).

collision_circle.description: Collision_circle creates a circular zone of the radius given by the user around the points x1,y1 and then checks that zone for a collision with **any** instance of the object specified by the argument "obj". This check can be either precise or not, but for precise collisions to be enabled, the object or instance that you are checking for *must* also have precise collisions enabled for their sprite. If not, the default check is based on bounding boxes. The following image illustrates how this works:

collision_circle_list.name: collision_circle_list

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the center of the circle to check.
The y coordinate of the center of the circle to check.
The radius (distance in pixels from its center to its edge).
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (`true`, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (`false`, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (`true`) or not (`false`).
The DS list to use to store the IDs of colliding instances.
Whether the list should be ordered by distance (`true`) or not (`false`).

collision_circle_list.description: This function is the same as the `collision_circle()` function, only instead of just detecting one instance in collision at a time, it will detect multiple instances. You supply the x/y position of the center of the circular area to check along with the radius and the object to check for, and you can set the check to be precise (in which case all instances being checked will need to have *precise* collision masks) and whether the check should include the calling instance or not.
collision_circle_list.returns: Int (The number of instances found to be in collision)

collision_ellipse.name: collision_ellipse

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left side of the ellipse to check.
The y coordinate of the top side of the ellipse to check.
The x coordinate of the right side of the ellipse to check.
The y coordinate of the bottom side of the ellipse to check.
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (`true`, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (`false`, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (`true`) or not (`false`).

collision_ellipse.description: Collision_ellipse uses the first four arguments (x1,y1,x2,y2) to define the width and height of an ellipse within the current room and then checks to see if **any** object that is defined by the "obj" argument is in collision with that area. This collision can be checked as precise or not, and you may also choose to check for the instance running the code itself or not. Consider this image:

collision_ellipse_list.name: collision_ellipse_list

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left side of the ellipse to check.
The y coordinate of the top side of the ellipse to check.
The x coordinate of the right side of the ellipse to check.
The y coordinate of the bottom side of the ellipse to check.
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (`true`, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (`false`, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (`true`) or not (`false`).
The DS list to use to store the IDs of colliding instances.
Whether the list should be ordered by distance (`true`) or not (`false`).

collision_ellipse_list.description: This function is the same as the `collision_ellipse()` function, only instead of just detecting one instance in collision at a time, it will detect multiple instances. You supply the x/y positions of the top left and bottom right of the elliptical area to check along with the object to check for, and you can set the check to be precise (in which case all instances being checked will need to have *precise* collision masks) and whether the check should include the calling instance or not.
collision_ellipse_list.returns: Int (The number of instances found to be in collision)

collision_line.name: collision_line

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the start of the line.
The y coordinate of the start of the line.
The x coordinate of the end of the line.
The y coordinate of the end of the line.
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (`true`, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (`false`, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (`true`) or not (`false`).

collision_line.description: Collision_line checks along a line from point x1,y1 to point x2,y2 for a collision with **any** instance of the object specified by the argument "obj". this check can be either precise or not, but for precise collisions to be enabled, the object or instance that you are checking for *must* also have precise collisions enabled for their sprite. If not, the default check is based on bounding boxes. The following image illustrates how this works:

collision_line_list.name: collision_line_list

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the start of the line.
The y coordinate of the start of the line.
The x coordinate of the end of the line.
The y coordinate of the end of the line.
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (`true`, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (`false`, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (`true`) or not (`false`).
The DS list to use to store the IDs of colliding instances.
Whether the list should be ordered by distance (`true`) or not (`false`).

collision_line_list.description: This function is the same as the `collision_line()` function, only instead of just detecting one instance in collision at a time, it will detect multiple instances. You supply the x/y positions of the start and end of the line to check along with the object to check for, and you can set the check to be precise (in which case all instances being checked will need to have *precise* collision masks) and whether the check should include the calling instance or not.
collision_line_list.returns: Integer (The number of instances found to be in collision)

collision_point.name: collision_point

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the point to check.
The y coordinate of the point to check.
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (`true`, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (`false`, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (`true`) or not (`false`).

collision_point.description: Collision_point checks the point specified by the arguments x1,y1 for a collision with **any** instance of the object specified by the argument "obj". this check can be either precise or not, but for precise collisions to be enabled, the object or instance that you are checking for *must* also have precise collisions enabled for their sprite. If not, the default check is based on bounding boxes. The following image illustrates how this works:

collision_point_list.name: collision_point_list

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the point to check.
The y coordinate of the point to check.
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (`true`, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (`false`, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (`true`) or not (`false`).
The DS list to use to store the IDs of colliding instances.
Whether the list should be ordered by distance (`true`) or not (`false`).

collision_point_list.description: This function is the same as the `collision_point()` function, only instead of just detecting one instance in collision at a time, it will detect multiple instances. You supply the x/y position of the point to check and you can set the check to be precise (in which case all instances being checked will need to have *precise* collision masks) and whether the check should include the calling instance or not.
collision_point_list.returns: Integer (The number of instances found to be in collision)

collision_rectangle.name: collision_rectangle

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left side of the rectangle to check.
The y coordinate of the top side of the rectangle to check.
The x coordinate of the right side of the rectangle to check.
The y coordinate of the bottom side of the rectangle to check.
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (`true`, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (`false`, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (`true`) or not (`false`).

collision_rectangle.description: Collision_rectangle uses the first four arguments (x1,y1,x2,y2) to define an area within the current room and then checks to see if **any** object that is defined by the "obj" argument is in collision with that area. This collision can be checked as precise or not, and you may also choose to check for the instance running the code itself or not. Consider this image:

collision_rectangle_list.name: collision_rectangle_list

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left side of the rectangle to check.
The y coordinate of the top side of the rectangle to check.
The x coordinate of the right side of the rectangle to check.
The y coordinate of the bottom side of the rectangle to check.
The object to check for instance collisions.
Whether the check is based on precise collisions (`true`, which is slower) or its bounding box in general (`false`, faster).
Whether the calling instance, if relevant, should be excluded (`true`) or not (`false`).
The DS list to use to store the IDs of colliding instances.
Whether the list should be ordered by distance (`true`) or not (`false`).

collision_rectangle_list.description: This function is the same as the `collision_rectangle()` function, only instead of just detecting one instance in collision at a time, it will detect multiple instances. You supply the x/y positions of the top left and bottom right of the area to check along with the object to check for, and you can set the check to be precise (in which case all instances being checked will need to have *precise* collision masks) and whether the check should include the calling instance or not.
collision_rectangle_list.returns: Integer (The number of instances found to be in collision)

colour_get_blue.name: colour_get_blue

parameters.description: The colour to check

colour_get_blue.example:
```
b_comp = colour_get_blue(c_teal);
```
The above code will get the blue component of the colour constant "c_teal" and store the value in the variable "b_comp".
colour_get_blue.description: This function returns the amount of blue used to make the given colour, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no blue and 255 is all blue. The following image illustrates this:

colour_get_green.name: colour_get_green

parameters.description: The colour to check

colour_get_green.example:
```
g_comp = colour_get_green(c_teal);
```
The above code will get the green component of the colour constant "c_teal" and store the value in the variable "g_comp".
colour_get_green.description: This function returns the amount of green used to make the given colour, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no green and 255 is all green. The following image illustrates this:

colour_get_hue.name: colour_get_hue

parameters.description: The colour to check

colour_get_hue.example:
```
col = merge_colour(colour_get_hue(c_teal), c_white, 0.5);
```
The above code gets the hue used to make the colour constant "c_teal" and then merges it with white at a 50:50 ratio, storing the resulting colour in the variable "col".
colour_get_hue.description:
This function will return the hue of the given colour. This is the "pure" colour tone which is part of the hue, saturation and value (luminosity) method for defining a colour. The following image illustrates how this value corresponds to the
    HSV scale of colour:

colour_get_red.name: colour_get_red

parameters.description: The colour to check

colour_get_red.example:
```
r_comp = colour_get_red(c_teal);
```
The above code will get the red component of the colour constant "c_teal" and store the value in the variable "r_comp".
colour_get_red.description: This function returns the amount of red used to make the given colour, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no red and 255 is all red. The following image illustrates this:

colour_get_saturation.name: colour_get_saturation

parameters.description: The colour to check

colour_get_saturation.example:
```
col = make_colour_hsv(random(255), colour_get_sat(c_teal), 255);
```
The above code gets the saturation used to make the colour constant "c_teal" and then uses that value to set a random colour to have the same saturation, storing the resulting colour in the variable "col".
colour_get_saturation.description:
This function will return the saturation of the given colour. This is the amount of the colour tone that is mixed into the final colour and is part of the hue, saturation and value (luminosity) method for defining a colour. The following image illustrates
    how this value corresponds to the HSV scale of colour:

colour_get_value.name: colour_get_value

parameters.description: The colour to check

colour_get_value.example:
```
col = make_colour_hsv(random(255), 255, colour_get_value(c_teal));
```
The above code gets the value used to make the colour constant "c_teal" and then uses that value to set a random colour to have the same luminosity, storing the resulting colour in the variable "col".
colour_get_value.description:
This function will return the value (luminosity) of the given colour. This is the amount of the "light" that is mixed into the final colour and is part of the hue, saturation and value method for defining a colour. The following image illustrates
    how this value corresponds to the HSV scale of colour:

cos.name: cos

parameters.description: The angle (in radians) to return the cosine of.

cos.example:
```
val = cos( 0 );
```
This will set val to 1.
cos.description: In a right angled triangle *cos(val) = Adjacent / Hypotenuse* where val is one of the three angles. This function will always return a number between 1 and -1.

darccos.name: darccos

parameters.description: The value to return the inverse cosine of.

darccos.example:
```
val = arccos(-1);
```
This will set "val" to 180.
darccos.description: Returns the inverse cosine of x, in that if dcos(val)=n, darccos(n)=val, and the resulting number will be between 180 and 0.

darcsin.name: darcsin

parameters.description: The value to return the inverse sine of.

darcsin.example:
```
val = darcsin(-1);
```
This will set "val" to -90.
darcsin.description: Returns the inverse sine of x, in that if dsin(x)=n, darcsin(n)=x, and the resulting number will be between -90 and 90.

darctan.name: darctan

parameters.description: The value to return the inverse tangent of.

darctan.example:
```
val = darctan(1);
```
This will set "val" to -45.
darctan.description:
Returns the inverse tangent of x. This will accept any number as, unlike dtan(), darctan() asymptotes are on the y axis so it just means you'll never get returned a number
    greater than 90 or less than -90.

darctan2.name: darctan2

parameters.description: The y coordinate to calculate.
The x coordinate to calculate.

darctan2.example:
```
val = darctan2(1, 1);
```
This will set "val" to the correct angle.
darctan2.description: This function returns the inverse tangent of an angle y/x, where y = Opposite side of triangle and x = Adjacent side of triangle. Unlike darctan()    the function darctan2() is valid for all angles and so may be used to convert a vector to an angle without risking division by zero, and it also returns a result in the correct quadrant.

date_compare_date.name: date_compare_date

parameters.description: The first date.
The date to compare it to.

date_compare_date.example:
```
d = date_compare_date(date_create_datetime(2011, 9, 15, 11, 4, 0), date_current_datetime());
```
This would set "d" to the corresponding value depending on which of the dates was the earliest, likely 1 since the current date would be further ahead than 15th September 2011.
date_compare_date.description: With this function you can check two dates to see which one is the earlier or later than the other. The function returns -1 if date1 is earlier, 0 if both dates are the same, and 1 if date1 is later.

date_compare_datetime.name: date_compare_datetime

parameters.description: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare it to.

date_compare_datetime.example:
```
d = date_compare_datetime(date_create_datetime(2011, 9, 15, 11, 4, 0), date_current_datetime());
```
This would set d to the corresponding value depending on which of the datetimes was the earliest, likely -1 since the current date would be further ahead than 15th September 2011.
date_compare_datetime.description:
With this function you can check two dates and times to see which one is the earlier or later than the other. The function returns -1 if date1 is earlier, 1 if date1 is later and 0 if they are the same, although since this takes time into account as
    well, a 0 for matching is very rare (it literally has to be the same second of the same day of the same month of the same year to return a 0).

date_compare_time.name: date_compare_time

parameters.description: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare the first one to.

date_compare_time.example:
```
d = date_compare_time(date_create_datetime( 2011, 9, 15, 11, 4, 0 ), date_current_datetime());
```
This would set "d" to the corresponding value depending on which of the times was the earliest. Basically, if the current time is later than 11:04 am, it would return 1. If earlier, -1. If the time is 11:04, it would return 0.
date_compare_time.description:
With this function you can check two dates and times to see which one has the time component earlier or later than the other. The function returns -1 if datetime1 is earlier, 1 if datetime1 is later and 0 if they are the same, and it ignores the date,
    so literally just which of the times is further through its given day.

date_create_datetime.name: date_create_datetime

parameters.description: The year to set.
The month to set.
The day to set.
The hour to set.
The minute to set.
The second to set.

date_create_datetime.example:
```
mydatetime = date_create_datetime(2011, 9, 15, 9, 43, 30);
```
This would set "mydatetime" to the given date and time and store the returned value in the variable "mydatetime".
date_create_datetime.description: This function will create a datetime value from the component given as the arguments.

date_current_datetime.name: date_current_datetime
date_current_datetime.example:
```
myhour = date_get_hour(date_current_datetime()); myday = date_get_day(date_current_datetime());
```
This would set local variable myhour to the hour of the current time, and myday to the day of the current date.
date_current_datetime.description: Returns the date-time value of the current moment. The time returned is based on the default time zone for the system (ie: local time). You can change the base time zone to use with the function `date_set_timezone()`

date_date_string.name: date_date_string

parameters.description: The date to use.

date_date_string.example:
```
str = date_date_string(date_current_datetime()); draw_text(32, 32, str);
```
This would set "str" to hold a formatted string of the current date and time as shown by the system.
date_date_string.description: With this function you can create a string containing the given date, formatted as day/month/year.

date_datetime_string.name: date_datetime_string

parameters.description: The date to use.

date_datetime_string.example:
```
str = date_datetime_string(date_current_datetime());
```
This would set "str" to something like "September 15th 2011, 11:33.00" depending on the system settings for date/time displaying and the current date and time.
date_datetime_string.description: With this function you can create a string containing the given datetime, formatted for the system or device that is running the game when the function is called.

date_day_span.name: date_day_span

parameters.description: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare it to.

date_day_span.example:
```
diff = date_day_span(date_create_datetime(2011, 9, 15, 11, 4, 0), date_current_datetime());
```
This would set diff to the number of days between 15th September 2011, 11:04.0 and the current date and time.
date_day_span.description: With this function you can get the number of days between two dates. This value is always positive, and incomplete days will be returned as a fraction.

date_days_in_month.name: date_days_in_month

parameters.description: The date to use.

date_days_in_month.example:
```
days = date_days_in_month(date_current_datetime());
```
This would set "days" to the number of days in the current month.
date_days_in_month.description: With this function you can get the number of days that the given month has, either 28, 29, 30 or 31.

date_days_in_year.name: date_days_in_year

parameters.description: The date to use.

date_days_in_year.example:
```
days = date_days_in_year(date_current_datetime());
```
This would set "days" to the number of days in the current year.
date_days_in_year.description: With this function you can get the number of days that the given year has, returning 365 for a normal year, and 366 for a leap year.

date_get_day.name: date_get_day

parameters.description: The date to check.

date_get_day.example:
```
myday = date_get_day( date_current_datetime() );
```
This would set "myday" to the current day.
date_get_day.description: This function returns the day (from 1 to 31) of the given datetime.

date_get_day_of_year.name: date_get_day_of_year

parameters.description: The date to check.

date_get_day_of_year.example:
```
mydayyear = date_get_day_of_year(date_current_datetime());
```
This would set mydayyear to the current day of the year.
date_get_day_of_year.description: This function returns the day (from 1 to 366) within the year of the given datetime.

date_get_hour.name: date_get_hour

parameters.description: The datetime to check.

date_get_hour.example:
```
myhour = date_get_hour(date_current_datetime());
```
This would set "myhour" to the current hour.
date_get_hour.description: This function returns the hour of the given datetime value.

date_get_hour_of_year.name: date_get_hour_of_year

parameters.description: The datetime to check.

date_get_hour_of_year.example:
```
myhouryear = date_get_hour_of_year(date_current_datetime());
```
This would set "myhouryear" to the current hour of the year.
date_get_hour_of_year.description: This function returns the hour of the given datetime value within the year (from the total number of hours for the year, taking into account leap years).

date_get_timezone.description: Gets the base time zone being used for all the rest of the date and time functions. This time zone can either be *local* (as set by the system) or *UTC*, and the function will return one of the following constants:

myweek = date_get_week(date_current_datetime());
```
This would set myweek to the current week.

```

```
This would set "myyear" to the current year.
date_get_year.description: This function returns the year of the given datetime.

date_hour_span.name: date_hour_span

parameters.description: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare the first one to.

```
diff = date_hour_span(date_create_datetime( 2011, 9, 15, 11, 4, 0 ), date_current_datetime());
```
This would set "diff" to the number of hours between 15th September 2011, 11:04.0 and the current date and time.
date_hour_span.description: With this function you can get the number of hours between two dates. This value is always positive, and incomplete hours will be returned as a fraction.

```
This would set "mynewdatetime" to the current date but with 365 days added.
date_inc_day.description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of days, and it will return the new datetime value.

parameters.description: The datetime to add to.

```
This would set mynewdatetime to the current date but with 24 hours added.
date_inc_hour.description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of hours, and it will return the new datetime value.

parameters.description: The datetime to add to.
The number of minutes (must be an integer) to add.

date_inc_minute.example:
```
mynewdatetime = date_inc_minute(date_current_datetime(), 60);
```
This would set "mynewdatetime" to the current date but with 60 minutes added.
date_inc_minute.description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of minutes, and it will return the new datetime value.

date_inc_month.name: date_inc_month

parameters.description: The datetime to add to.
The number of months (must be an integer) to add.

mynewdatetime = date_inc_month(date_current_datetime(), 12);
```
This would set "mynewdatetime" to the current date but with 12 months added.
date_inc_month.description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of months, and it will return the new datetime value.

parameters.description: The datetime to add to.
The number of seconds (must be an integer) to add.

date_inc_second.example:
```
mynewdatetime = date_inc_second(date_current_datetime(), 60);
```
This would set "mynewdatetime" to the current date but with 60 seconds added.
date_inc_second.description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of seconds, and it will return the new datetime value.

This would set mynewdatetime to the current date but with 52 weeks added.

The number of years (must be an integer) to add.

date_inc_year.description: With this function you can increment a given datetime value by a specific number of years, and it will return the new datetime value.

date_is_today.name: date_is_today

parameters.description: The datetime to use.

date_is_today.description: This function will return `true` if the given datetime value is the day it is being checked on (ie: today), or `false` otherwise. This can be a handy function for things like Easter Eggs in your games, or for unlocking seasonal content. Note that this function will be affected by the time zone set (default is local time) which you can change using the `date_set_timezone()` function.

date_leap_year.name: date_leap_year

parameters.description: The datetime to use.

date_leap_year.description: This function will return `true` if the year component of the given datetime value is a leap year or `false` otherwise. This can be a handy function for things like Easter Eggs in your games, or for unlocking special content.

date_minute_span.name: date_minute_span

parameters.description: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare it to.

date_minute_span.example:
```
diff = date_minute_span(date_create_datetime(2011, 9, 15, 11, 4, 0 ), date_current_datetime());
```
This would set "diff" to the number of minutes between 15th September 2011, 11:04.0 and the current date and time.
date_minute_span.description: With this function you can get the number of minutes between two dates. This value is always positive, and incomplete minutes will be returned as a fraction.

date_month_span.name: date_month_span

parameters.description: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare it to.

date_month_span.example:
```
diff = date_month_span(date_create_datetime(2011, 9, 15, 11, 4, 0 ), date_current_datetime());
```
This would set "diff" to the number of months between 15th September 2011, 11:04.0 and the current date and time.
date_month_span.description: With this function you can get the number of months between two dates. This value is always positive, and incomplete months will be returned as a fraction.

date_second_span.name: date_second_span

parameters.description: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare it to.

date_second_span.example:
```
diff = date_second_span(date_create_datetime(2011, 9, 15, 11, 4, 0 ), date_current_datetime());
```
This would set "diff" to the number of seconds between 15th September 2011, 11:04 and the current date and time.
date_second_span.description: With this function you can get the number of seconds between two dates. The return value is always positive and will be a whole number.

date_set_timezone.name: date_set_timezone

parameters.description: The time zone to use for the base time.

date_set_timezone.description: Sets the base time zone to use for all the rest of the date and time functions. This time zone can either be *local* (as set by the system) or *UTC*, and you would use one of the following constants to define which is being used (by default this is local time):

date_time_of.name: date_time_of

parameters.description: The datetime to extract the time from.

date_time_of.example:
```
time = date_time_of(date_current_datetime());
```
This would return the current time only and store the value in the variable "time".
date_time_of.description: Returns the time value of the given datetime. The time returned ignores Daylight Saving Time (and so is Universal Time) and would normally be used in conjunction with another date/time handling function.

date_time_string.name: date_time_string

parameters.description: The datetime to use.

date_time_string.example:
```
str = date_time_string(date_current_datetime());
```
This would set the given variable to something like "11:36.00" depending on the system settings for date/time displaying and the current date and time.
date_time_string.description: With this function you can create a string containing the given time, formatted for the system or device that is running the game when the function is called.

date_valid_datetime.name: date_valid_datetime

parameters.description: The year to check.
The month to check.
The day to check.
The hour to check.
The minute to check.
The second to check.

date_valid_datetime.description: With this function you can check a datetime value to see if it is valid (returns `true`) or not (returns `false`). Note that this function will only consider a valid datetime as being *after* 1/1/1970 and anything before that will return `false`, so the earliest you can check would be:

parameters.description: The first datetime.
The datetime to compare it to.

diff = date_week_span( date_create_datetime( 2011, 9, 15, 11, 4, 0 ), date_current_datetime() );
```
This would set "diff" to the number of weeks between 15th September 2011, 11:04.0 and the current date and time.
date_week_span.description: With this function you can get the number of weeks between two dates. This value is always positive, and incomplete weeks will be returned as a fraction.

date_year_span.name: date_year_span

parameters.description: The first datetime.

diff = date_year_span(date_create_datetime(2011, 9, 15, 11, 4, 0), date_current_datetime());
```
This would set diff to the number of years between 15th September 2011, 11:04.0 and the current date and time.
date_year_span.description: With this function you can get the number of years between two dates. This value is always positive, and incomplete years will be returned as a fraction.

dcos.name: dcos

parameters.description: The angle (in degrees) to return the cosine of.

dcos.example:
```
val = dcos(45);
```
This will set "val" to 0.71.
dcos.description: In a right angled triangle *cos(val) = Adjacent / Hypotenuse* where val is one of the three angles. This function will always return a number between 1 and -1.

debug_event.name: debug_event

parameters.description: The custom debug event string to use.

debug_event.description: This function generates a custom debug event that will be shown in the Graph View of the debugger when a game is being run in  [Debug Mode](https://manual.yoyogames.com/Introduction/Debugging.htm). If you require messages to be displayed when *not* in debug mode, then you should be using `show_debug_message()`. It is worth noting that the function will also take two reserved strings to help perform debugging using external applications like Visual Studio. These strings are:

debug_get_callstack.name: debug_get_callstack

parameters.description: The maximum depth of the callstack

debug_get_callstack.description: This function generates an array of strings as the "callstack" where the current script is listed first, and then all the other scripts that were run in order for the current script to be executed. The exact string format will vary depending on the target platform chosen, but it will mostly have the script/event name, then a colon : and the line number, similar to this:

degtorad.name: degtorad

parameters.description: The degrees to convert.

degtorad.example:
```
val = degtorad(90);
```
This will set val to pi/2.
degtorad.description:
In GM all the trigonometric functions work in radians, but most people work in degrees and this means that to convert your degrees into radians you need to use this function. For example, `degtorad(180) `returns 3.14159265 radians. This function
    translates degrees into radians using the formula:

device_get_tilt_x.name: device_get_tilt_x
device_get_tilt_x.description: This function returns a value between -1 and 1 depending upon the angle of "tilt" of the device. The actual correlation between degrees of tilt and the value returned depends on the device and OS that it uses, but generally a value of 1 or -1 is the same as +/-90. The image below shows how each if the available functions relates to the device:

device_get_tilt_y.name: device_get_tilt_y
device_get_tilt_y.description: This function returns a value between -1 and 1 depending upon the angle of "tilt" of the device. The actual correlation between degrees of tilt and the value returned depends on the device and OS that it uses, but generally a value of 1 or -1 is the same as +/-90. The image below shows how each if the available functions relates to the device:

device_get_tilt_z.name: device_get_tilt_z
device_get_tilt_z.example:
```
y += sign(device_get_tilt_z());
```
The above code uses the tilt value to move the player along the y axis.
device_get_tilt_z.description:
This function returns a value between -1 and 1 depending upon the angle of "tilt" of the device. The actual correlation between degrees of tilt and the value returned depends on the device and OS that it uses, but generally a value of 1 or
    -1 is the same as +/-90. The image below shows how each if the available functions relates to the device:

device_mouse_check_button.name: device_mouse_check_button

parameters.description: The device (from 0 - *n*) that is being checked
The button of the device that is being checked.

device_mouse_check_button.description: This function returns `true` or `false` depending on whether the given **mouse button** is being held down on the given **device**. For the mouse button you can supply one of the constants listed  [on this page](https://manual.yoyogames.com/GameMaker_Language/GML_Reference/Game_Input/Mouse_Input/Mouse_Input.htm).

device_mouse_check_button_pressed.name: device_mouse_check_button_pressed

parameters.description: The device (from 0 - *n*) that is being checked.
The button of the device that is being checked.

device_mouse_check_button_pressed.description: This function returns `true` or `false` depending on whether the device that you specify has been "touched" (clicked) or not. The device argument refers to the touch number, which can be from 0 to n and the maximum number of touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs (most devices will support at least 4 simultaneous touches). This function is only triggered *once *by the actual pressing action, and the constants listed  [on this page](https://manual.yoyogames.com/GameMaker_Language/GML_Reference/Game_Input/Mouse_Input/Mouse_Input.htm) can be used to check for the mouse buttons. Note that `mb_right` will only be detected if a double tap touch is detected and held on the second tap (this behavior can be disabled using the function  [device_mouse_dbclick_enable()](https://manual.yoyogames.com/GameMaker_Language/GML_Reference/Game_Input/Device_Input/device_mouse_dbclick_enable.htm)).

device_mouse_check_button_released.name: device_mouse_check_button_released

parameters.description: The device (from 0 - *n*) that is being checked.
The button of the device that is being checked.

device_mouse_check_button_released.description: This function returns `true` or `false` depending on whether the device touch that you specify has been released or not. The device argument refers to the device touch number, which can be from 0 to n and note that the maximum number of touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs (most devices will support at least 4 simultaneous touches). This function is only triggered once by the actual releasing action, and the constants listed  [on this page](https://manual.yoyogames.com/GameMaker_Language/GML_Reference/Game_Input/Mouse_Input/Mouse_Input.htm) can be used to check for the mouse buttons. Note that `mb_right` will only have been detected if a double tap touch is detected and held on the second tap before release (this behavior can be disabled using the function  [device_mouse_dbclick_enable()](https://manual.yoyogames.com/GameMaker_Language/GML_Reference/Game_Input/Device_Input/device_mouse_dbclick_enable.htm)).

device_mouse_dbclick_enable.name: device_mouse_dbclick_enable

parameters.description: Set double-click detection on (`true`) or off (`false`).

device_mouse_dbclick_enable.description: This function can be used to set the device to detect a double tap of the `mb_left` (left mouse button) as an `mb_right` (right mouse button) tap or not. By default this is set to `true`, meaning that every time the user taps the device screen twice quickly and consecutively, the return value is the same as if the right mouse button had been clicked. When this is on, the first tap will be detected as `mb_left`, and the second as `mb_right`, so make sure that any code you use takes this into account.

device_mouse_raw_x.name: device_mouse_raw_x

parameters.description: The device (from 0 - *n*) that is being checked.

device_mouse_raw_x.description: This function returns the raw x position of a touch on the device. What this means is that it returns the actual device definition of the x position that is being touched, *not* the GameMaker Studio 2 one, and as such will ignore things like view position and scaling. Note that the maximum number of touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs

device_mouse_raw_y.name: device_mouse_raw_y

parameters.description: The device (from 0 - *n*) that is being checked.

device_mouse_raw_y.description: This function returns raw y position of the touch on a device. What this means is that it returns the actual device definition of the y position that is being touched, *not* the GameMaker Studio 2 one, and as such will ignore things like view position and scaling. Note that the maximum number of device touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs

device_mouse_x.name: device_mouse_x

parameters.description: The device (from 0 - *n*) that is being checked.

device_mouse_x.description: This function returns the x position of a touch on the device. If you are running this on a the HTML5 or PC and Mac modules then this value is updated constantly, as long as the device (usually a mouse) is plugged in, however for mobile devices, this will only be updated while the screen is being touched and note that the maximum number of touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs.

device_mouse_x_to_gui.name: device_mouse_x_to_gui

parameters.description: The device (from 0 - *n*) that is being checked.

device_mouse_x_to_gui.description: This function returns the x position of the touch on the device in relation to the GUI layer. Since the GUI layer can be set to be a different size independently of the screen resolution *and* the room size, it can sometimes be complicated to get the exact point on the GUI layer that a user has touched the screen. With this function you can get that position based on the actual GUI size, making GUI buttons and HUD elements easier to create and interact with. If you are running this on a the HTML5 or PC and Mac modules then this value is updated constantly, as long as the device (usually a mouse) is plugged in, however for mobile devices, this will only be updated while the screen is being touched, and note that the maximum number of touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs.

device_mouse_y.name: device_mouse_y

parameters.description: The device (from 0 - *n*) that is being checked.

device_mouse_y.description: This function returns the y position of a touch on the device. If you are running this on a the HTML5 or PC and Mac modules then this value is updated constantly, as long as the device (usually a mouse) is plugged in, however for mobile devices, this will only be updated while the screen is being touched and note that the maximum number of touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs.

device_mouse_y_to_gui.name: device_mouse_y_to_gui

parameters.description: The device (from 0 - *n*) that is being checked.

device_mouse_y_to_gui.description: This function returns the y position of the touch on the device in relation to the GUI layer. Since the GUI layer can be set to be a different size independently of the screen resolution *and* the room size, it can sometimes be complicated to get the exact point on the GUI layer that a user has touched the screen. With this function you can get that position based on the actual GUI size, making GUI buttons and HUD elements easier to create and interact with. If you are running this on a the HTML5 or PC and Mac modules then this value is updated constantly, as long as the device (usually a mouse) is plugged in, however for mobile devices, this will only be updated while the screen is being touched, and note that the maximum number of touches that can be detected will depend very much on the device being used and the OS it runs.

directory_create.name: directory_create

parameters.description: The name of the directory to create.

directory_create.description: This function will creates a directory with the given name in the save area.

directory_destroy.name: directory_destroy

parameters.description: The name of the directory to remove.

directory_destroy.description: This function will remove a directory with the given name in the save area.

directory_exists.name: directory_exists

parameters.description: The name of the directory to look for.

directory_exists.description: This function will return `true` if the indicated directory exists or `false` if it does not. The specified name must include the full path, not a relative path and by default you cannot access any directories from out-with the game bundle as all games are sandboxed (see the section on the  [File System](https://manual.yoyogames.com/Additional_Information/The_File_System.htm) for more information).

display_get_dpi_x.name: display_get_dpi_x
display_get_dpi_x.example:
```
dpx = display_get_dpi_x();
```
This would set the variable "dpx" to the dpi value of the x axis.
display_get_dpi_x.description: Dots per inch (DPI) is a measure of spatial printing or video dot density, in particular the number of individual dots that can be placed in a line within the span of 1 inch (2.54 cm). When working on mobile devices (in particular Android devices) this is an important factor to take into consideration as what may be appropriate for one display resolution, may not be appropriate for another. For example, you may have two displays with the same resolution of 400 x 800, but display 1 has a dpi of 60 and display 2 has a dpi of 30. In this case, any text or image displayed on display 2 will appear much larger, even though the actual resolution is the same.

display_get_dpi_y.name: display_get_dpi_y
display_get_dpi_y.example:
```
dpy = display_get_dpi_y();
```
This would set the variable "dpy" to the dpi value of the y axis.
display_get_dpi_y.description:
Dots per inch (DPI) is a measure of spatial printing or video dot density, in particular the number of individual dots that can be placed in a line within the span of 1 inch (2.54 cm). When working on mobile devices (in particular Android devices) this
    is an important factor to take into consideration as what may be appropriate for one display resolution, may not be appropriate for another. For example, you may have two displays with the same resolution of 400 x 800, but display 1 has a dpi of 60
    and display 2 has a dpi of 30. In this case, any text or image displayed on display 2 will appear much larger, even though the actual resolution is the same.

display_get_frequency.name: display_get_frequency
display_get_frequency.description: This function returns the frequency (or refresh rate) of the display that the game is being played on. It will return a real value as frames-per-second, so for example if your monitor is 60hz you will get 60, if it's running at 144hz then you will get 144, and so on.

display_get_gui_width.name: display_get_gui_width
display_get_gui_width.example:
```
ads_move(display_get_gui_width() - ads_get_display_width(0), 0, 0);
```
The above code will set an advert to display at the top right-hand of the display.
display_get_gui_width.description: With this function you can get the width (in pixels) of the GUI as used in the  [Draw GUI Event](https://manual.yoyogames.com/The_Asset_Editors/Object_Properties/Draw_Events.htm).

display_get_height.name: display_get_height
display_get_height.example:
```
myheight = display_get_height();
```
This would set the variable "myheight" to the display's height.
display_get_height.description: This function will return the height of the display (in pixels). Note that on the HTML5 target, this value is the height of the *browser window*, rather than the physical display size.

display_get_orientation.name: display_get_orientation
display_get_orientation.description: This function will return one of two constants GameMaker Studio 2 has to tell you whether the device running the game is being held in landscape or portrait mode (see the table below). Note that this function may not correctly detect the orientation of the device when used in the HTML5 target module. However this is easily mimicked by the use of the following script:

display_get_sleep_margin.name: display_get_sleep_margin
display_get_sleep_margin.description: This function can be used to get the current sleep margin value used for the render timing of your game, and will return a millisecond value. For more information on display timing, please see `display_set_timing_method()`.

display_get_timing_method.name: display_get_timing_method
display_get_timing_method.description: This function can be used to retrieve the timing method to be used for rendering your game. The method can be one of the constants listed below.

display_get_width.name: display_get_width
display_get_width.example:
```
mywidth = display_get_width();
```
This would set the variable "mywidth" to the display's width.
display_get_width.description: This function will return the width of the display (in pixels). Note that on the HTML5 target, this value is the width of the *browser window*, rather than the physical display size.

display_mouse_get_x.name: display_mouse_get_x
display_mouse_get_x.example:
```
my_x = display_mouse_get_x();
```
This would set my_x to the x coordinate of the mouse relative to the display.
display_mouse_get_x.description:
This function will return the mouse x position within the *screen*. It should be noted that this function only works properly when used on the Windows target. It can be used for HTML5 too, but will only return a value *relative* to the 0,0
    of the canvas itself, and will not return any value while the mouse is outside of the canvas. For other devices it will return 0, and you should use the `device_mouse_raw_x()`and
    `device_mouse_raw_y()` functions instead.

display_mouse_get_y.name: display_mouse_get_y
display_mouse_get_y.example:
```
my_y = display_mouse_get_y();
```
This would set my_y to the y coordinate of the mouse relative to the display.
display_mouse_get_y.description:
This function will return the mouse y position within the *screen*. It should be noted that this function only works properly when used on the Windows target. It can be used for HTML5 too, but will only return a value *relative* to the 0,0
    of the canvas itself, and will not return any value while the mouse is outside of the canvas. For other devices it will return 0, and you should use the `device_mouse_raw_x()`    and `device_mouse_raw_y()` functions instead.

display_mouse_set.name: display_mouse_set

parameters.description: The x coordinate in the display.
The y coordinate in the display.

display_mouse_set.example:
```
display_mouse_set(display_get_width() / 2, display_get_height() / 2);
```
The above code would center the mouse in the game display.
display_mouse_set.description: With this function you can change or set the position of the mouse within the game display which can be useful for FPS games, for example. The function will only work while the game is in focus and using `ALT + Tab` will unlock the mouse.

display_reset.name: display_reset

parameters.description: The level of anti-aliasing filtering (0, 2, 4 or 8).
Toggle vertical synchronisation to on (true) or off (false).

display_reset.description: This function Resets the display settings to the ones that were set when the game was started, but also allows you to change the current level of full screen anti-aliasing being used and whether to use vertical synchronisation. The available anti-aliasing levels are 0,2,4 and 8, with the default startup value being set to 0, and the default v-sync setting is false (off). Switching v-sync on may give a smoother gaming experience but it will also need more processing power and so its impact must be considered careful before use, and the same goes for the anti-aliasing where the higher the number the more processing that is required.

display_set_gui_maximise.name: display_set_gui_maximise

parameters.description: *<Optional>* The horizontal scaling factor (use -1 to reset to default).
*<Optional>* The vertical scaling factor (use -1 to reset to default).
*<Optional>* The x offset position for drawing.
*<Optional>* The y offset position for drawing.

display_set_gui_maximise.example:
```
display_set_gui_size(display_get_width() / 2, display_get_height() / 2); display_set_gui_maximise(2, 2, 0, 0);
```
The above code will lock the draw GUI event to the given width and height, scaling all components to fit the display, using that proportion.
display_set_gui_maximise.description:
This function can be used to maximise the GUI layer and set it to be scaled and offset in relation to the screen dimensions, rather than the default application surface position and dimensions. By default, the GUI layer is 1:1 with the application surface
    resolution and drawn at the (0,0) position of the surface too. However this is not always what you want and so you can use this function to set it to be drawn relative to the absolute (0,0) position of the display or game window. What arguments you
    provide to this function will depend on the effect you wish it to have on the GUI layer. Simply calling the function with no arguments will set the GUI layer to be drawn at the (0,0) position of the screen or game window, with the width and height
    being scaled to fit the whole area:

display_set_gui_size.name: display_set_gui_size

parameters.description: The width of the GUI
The height of the GUI

display_set_gui_size.example:
```
display_set_gui_size(768, 1024);
```
The above code will lock the draw GUI event to the given width and height, scaling all components to fit either the application surface, or the display, using that proportion.
display_set_gui_size.description:
This function will only affect things drawn in the  [Draw GUI Event](https://manual.yoyogames.com/The_Asset_Editors/Object_Properties/Draw_Events.htm) and can be used to set a specific width and height for all GUI components in that event, and no matter what
    size of display or window is used to display the GUI, it will be scaled to fit correctly. Where the GUI is positioned (ie: the (0,0) position) will depend on whether you have used the function `display_set_gui_maximise()`    or not. If you do not use this function (the default setting) then the GUI layer will be positioned with its (0,0) point at the same position as that for the application surface (the area where your game is being drawn) and the width and height will
    be stretched to fit the this surface, such that setting a GUI width of 256px with this function when the application surface is 512px would stretch those 256 pixels to fit, effectively making the pixels twice as large. This is ideal for those games
    that have aspect ratio correction set in the global Game Settings.

display_set_sleep_margin.name: display_set_sleep_margin

parameters.description: The number of milliseconds for the sleep margin

display_set_sleep_margin.description: This function can be used to set the sleep margin value used for the render timing of your game, and requires a millisecond value. The default values are as follows:

display_set_timing_method.name: display_set_timing_method

parameters.description: The timing method to use (see the list of constants, above)

display_set_timing_method.description: This function can be used to set the timing method to be used for rendering your game. The method can be one of the following constants:

display_set_ui_visibility.name: display_set_ui_visibility

parameters.description: The Android SYSTEM flags to use (as an integer value).

display_set_ui_visibility.example:
```
var flags = 1024|4096; display_set_ui_visibility(flags);
  
```
The above code will use the Android system flags "SYSTEM_UI_FLAG_IMMERSIVE_STICKY" and "SYSTEM_UI_FLAG_LAYOUT_FULLSCREEN" to set the visibility of the display.
display_set_ui_visibility.description:
This function can be used to show or hide the system UI on **Android** *only*. The function requires you to supply one or more system *flags* as an integer value. When using more than a single flag, these need to be merged using the bitwise
    "or", as shown in the example below. You can find a list of Android system flags  [here](https://manual.yoyogames.com/GameMaker_Language/GML_Reference/Cameras_And_Display/https://developer.android.com/reference/android/view/View.html#SYSTEM_UI_FLAG_FULLSCREEN).

distance_to_object.name: distance_to_object

parameters.description: The object to check for.

distance_to_object.description: This function calculates the distance from the edge of the bounding box of the calling instance to the nearest edge of the nearest instance of the object specified. The object can be an object index or a specific instance ID as well as the *keyword* **other**, and the distance is returned in pixels. Note that if either of the objects have no sprite or no mask defined, the results will be incorrect.

distance_to_point.name: distance_to_point

parameters.description: The x position to check.
The y position to check.

distance_to_point.description: This function calculates the distance from the edge of the bounding box of the calling instance to the specified x/y position in the room, with the return value being in pixels. Note that if the calling object have no sprite or no mask defined, the results will be incorrect.

dot_product.name: dot_product

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the first vector.
The y coordinate of the first vector.
The x coordinate of the second vector.
The y coordinate of the second vector.

dot_product.example:
```
var x1, y1, x2, y2; x1 = lengthdir_x(1, image_angle); y1 = lengthdir_y(1, image_angle); x2 = o_Player.x - x; y2 = o_Player.y - y; if dot_product(x1, y1, x2, y2) > 0 seen=true else seen=false;
```
The above code creates a vector using the instances image angle, and then gets the vector of the player object "o_Player" to itself. Finally it calculates the dot product of these two vectors and if it is greater than 0 it sets the variable
    "seen" to true, and if it is equal to or less than 0 it sets it to "false".
dot_product.description:
The dot product is a value expressing the angular relationship between two vectors and is found by taking two vectors, multiplying them together and then adding the results. The name "dot product" is derived from the centered dot ""
    that is often used to designate this operation (the alternative name "scalar product" emphasizes the scalar rather than vector nature of the result).

dot_product_3d.name: dot_product_3d

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the first vector.
The y coordinate of the first vector.
The z coordinate of the first vector.
The x coordinate of the second vector.
The y coordinate of the second vector.
The z coordinate of the second vector.

dot_product_3d.example:
```
var x1, y1, x2, y2; x1 = 0; y1 = 1; z1 = 0; x2 = o_Player.x - x; y2 = o_Player.y - y; z2 = o_Player.z - z; if dot_product_3d(x1, y1, z1, x2, y2, z2) > 0 above=true else above=false;
```
The above code creates a vector normal along the instances y (up) axis, and then gets the vector of the player object "o_Player" to itself. Finally it calculates the dot product of these two vectors and if it is greater tan 0 it sets the variable
    "above" to true, and if it is less than or equal to 0 it sets it to "false".
dot_product_3d.description:
The dot product is a value expressing the angular relationship between two vectors and is found by taking two vectors, multiplying them together and then adding the results. The name "dot product" is derived from the centered dot ""
    that is often used to designate this operation (the alternative name "scalar product" emphasizes the scalar rather than vector nature of the result).

dot_product_3d_normalised.name: dot_product_3d_normalised

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the first vector.
The y coordinate of the first vector.
The z coordinate of the first vector.
The x coordinate of the second vector.
The y coordinate of the second vector.
The z coordinate of the second vector.

dot_product_3d_normalised.example:
```
var x1, y1, x2, y2; x1 = 0; y1 = 1; z1 = 0; x2 = o_Player.x - x; y2 = o_Player.y - y; z2 = o_Player.z - z; if dot_product_3d_normalised(x1, y1, z1, x2, y2, z2) > 0 above=true else above=false;
```
The above code creates a vector normal along the instances y (up) axis, and then gets the vector of the player object "o_Player" to itself. Finally it calculates the dot product of these two vectors and if it is greater tan 0 it sets the variable
    "above" to true, and if it is less than or equal to 0 it sets it to "false".
dot_product_3d_normalised.description:
The dot product is a value expressing the angular relationship between two vectors and is found by taking two vectors, multiplying them together and then adding the results. The name "dot product" is derived from the centered dot ""
    that is often used to designate this operation (the alternative name "scalar product" emphasizes the scalar rather than vector nature of the result).

dot_product_normalised.name: dot_product_normalised

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the first vector.
The y coordinate of the first vector.
The x coordinate of the second vector.
The y coordinate of the second vector.

dot_product_normalised.example:
```
var x1, y1, x2, y2; x1 = lengthdir_x(1, image_angle); y1 = lengthdir_y(1, image_angle); x2 = o_Player.x - x; y2 = o_Player.y - y; if dot_product_normalised(x1, y1, x2, y2) > 0 seen=true else seen=false;
```
The above code creates a vector using the instances image angle, and then gets the vector of the player object "o_Player" to itself. Finally it calculates the dot product of these two vectors and if it is greater than 0 it sets the variable
    "seen" to true, and if it is equal to or less than 0 it sets it to "false".
dot_product_normalised.description:
The dot product is a value expressing the angular relationship between two vectors and is found by taking two vectors, multiplying them together and then adding the results. The name "dot product" is derived from the centered dot ""
    that is often used to designate this operation (the alternative name "scalar product" emphasizes the scalar rather than vector nature of the result).

draw_arrow.name: draw_arrow

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the start of the line.
The y coordinate of the start of the line.
The x coordinate of the end of the line (where the arrowhead ends).
The y coordinate of the end of the line (where the arrowhead ends).
The length of the arrow in pixels.

draw_arrow.example:
```
draw_arrow(x, y, mouse_x, mouse_y, 10);
```
The above code will draw an arrow from the position of the instance to the position of the mouse, with the arrow head being 10 pixels long.
draw_arrow.description:
This function will draw an arrow from point (x1,y1) to point (x2,y2). The stem of the arrow is drawn along these points with the actual arrow head being drawn at the end, where the size of the arrowhead is defined by the argument "size" and
    is calculated as being part of the stem so that the end point is always aligned with the position defined by x2,y2. The width of the arrow head is calculated automatically in proportion to the length.

draw_button.name: draw_button

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the button
The y coordinate of the top of the button
The x coordinate of the right of the button
The y coordinate of the bottom of the button
Whether the button is up (`true`) or down (`false`)

draw_button.example:
```
draw_button(100, 100, 200, 150, !mouse_check_button(mb_left));
```
This will draw a button which will appear pressed if the left mouse button is held down.
draw_button.description: This function will draw a very simple, rectangular "button" using the currently selected draw colour and alpha where the *up* argument defines how the beveled edge effect looks, as shown in the image below:

draw_circle.name: draw_circle

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the center of the circle.
The y coordinate of the center of the circle.
The circle's radius (length from its center to its edge)
Whether the circle is drawn filled (`false`) or as a one pixel wide outline (`true`).

draw_circle.example:
```
draw_set_colour(c_white); draw_circle(100, 100, 50, true);
```
This will draw a one pixel wide white circle outline with a radius of 50 pixels.
draw_circle.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a circle or a filled circle. You can define how precise the drawing is with the function `draw_set_circle_precision()`.

draw_circle_colour.name: draw_circle_colour

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the center of the circle.
The y coordinate of the center of the circle.
The radius (distance from center to edge) of the circle in pixels.
The colour at the center of the circle.
The colour at the edge of the circle.
Whether the circle is an outline (`true`) or not (`false`). If true, col1 is irrelevant.

draw_circle_colour.example:
```
draw_circle_colour(x, y, 100, c_white, c_black, false);
```
This would draw a filled circle with its center at the executing instance's x and y position, with a radius of 100 pixels, from white in the center to black at the outside.
draw_circle_colour.description:
With this function you can draw either an outline of a circle or a filled circle, and if it is filled you can define the interior and exterior fill colours. If these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other and
    the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function `draw_set_colour()`. You can define how precise the drawing is with the function `draw_set_circle_precision()`.

draw_clear.name: draw_clear

parameters.description: The colour with which the screen will be cleared

draw_clear.example:
```
draw_clear(c_blue);
```
This will clear the screen with the colour blue.
draw_clear.description: This function can be used to clear the entire screen (with no alpha blend) to the given colour, and is only for use in the draw event of an instance (it will not show if used in any other event). It can also be useful for clearing  [surfaces](https://manual.yoyogames.com/GameMaker_Language/GML_Reference/Drawing/Surfaces/Surfaces.htm)    when they are newly created.

draw_clear_alpha.name: draw_clear_alpha

parameters.description: The colour with which the screen will be cleared
The transparency of the colour with which the screen will be cleared

draw_clear_alpha.example:
```
draw_clear_alpha(c_red, 0.5);
```
This will clear the screen with 50% (0.5) transparency with the colour red.
draw_clear_alpha.description:
This function can be used to clear the entire screen with a given colour and the alpha component of the destination is set to the value you have set - this function does *not* do any blending as it works but any subsequent blend operations can
    be set up to use the destination alpha that you have set. This is only for use in the draw event of an instance (it will not show if used in any other event), and it can also be very useful for clearing  [surfaces](https://manual.yoyogames.com/GameMaker_Language/GML_Reference/Drawing/Surfaces/Surfaces.htm)    when they are newly created.

draw_ellipse.name: draw_ellipse

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the ellipse.
The y coordinate of the top of the ellipse.
The x coordinate of the right of the ellipse.
The y coordinate of the bottom of the ellipse.
Whether the ellipse is drawn filled (false) or as a one pixel wide outline (true).

draw_ellipse.example:
```
draw_set_colour(c_white); draw_ellipse(100, 100, 300, 200, false);
```
This will draw a filled ellipse within the defined rectangular area.
draw_ellipse.description: With this function you can draw either an outline of an ellipse or a filled ellipse by defining a rectangular area that will then have the ellipse created to fit. You can define how precise the drawing is with the function `draw_set_circle_precision()`.

draw_ellipse_colour.name: draw_ellipse_colour

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the ellipse.
The y coordinate of the top of the ellipse.
The x coordinate of the right of the ellipse.
The y coordinate of the bottom of the ellipse.
The colour of the center.
The colour of the edge.
Whether the ellipse is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

draw_ellipse_colour.example:
```
draw_ellipse_colour(50, 50, 200, 100, c_black, c_white, false);
```
This would draw a filled-in, horizontally-stretched ellipse with a black center and white edge.
draw_ellipse_colour.description:
With this function you can draw either an outline of an ellipse or a filled ellipse by defining a rectangular area that will then have the ellipse created to fit. If it is filled you can define the interior and exterior fill colours. If these colours
    are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function `draw_set_colour()`). You can define how
    precise the drawing is with the function `draw_set_circle_precision()`.

draw_enable_drawevent.name: draw_enable_drawevent

parameters.description: Set to `true` or `false`.

draw_enable_drawevent.description: With this function you can choose to enable (`true`) or disable (`false`) the draw event for **all instances in the game**, thus giving you control over how and when things are drawn, which is useful if you wish to implement a "frame skip" technique. Note that this doesn't just prevent instances drawing to the screen, it suppresses the draw event completely meaning that care should be taken since any game logic that is present in that event will not be run either.

draw_enable_swf_aa.name: draw_enable_swf_aa

parameters.description: Enable (`true`) or disable (`false`) AA for all SWF sprites.

draw_enable_swf_aa.description: With this function you can enable or disable anti-aliasing (AA) for SWF format vector sprites. AA simply smooths the edges of vector images to give them a nicer look. The amount of AA used will depend on the value set using the function `draw_set_swf_aa_level()`. By default this is disabled.

draw_flush.name: draw_flush
draw_flush.example:
```
draw_flush();
```
The above code flushes the draw pipeline.
draw_flush.description:
With this function you can flush the entire draw pipeline. This is a **debug only** function and in general *it should not be used* unless indicated by a member of the YoYo Games Support
      staff, as indiscriminate use will cause serious performance issues with your game.

draw_get_alpha.name: draw_get_alpha
draw_get_alpha.description: This function returns the current value of the draw alpha, which will range between 0 (fully transparent) and 1 (fully opaque). The draw alpha affects the transparency of all draw functions, and can be set with the  [draw_set_alpha()](https://manual.yoyogames.com/GameMaker_Language/GML_Reference/Drawing/Colour_And_Alpha/draw_set_alpha.htm) function.

draw_get_colour.name: draw_get_colour
draw_get_colour.description: This function returns the current draw colour which is used for drawing forms, text, primitives and un-textured 3D models. This can be set with the `draw_set_colour()` function.

draw_get_font.name: draw_get_font
draw_get_font.description: This function will get the font currently assigned for drawing text. The function will return -1 if no font is set, or the ID value (a positive integer) for the font resource assigned.

draw_get_halign.name: draw_get_halign
draw_get_halign.description: This function is used to get the text alignment setting along the horizontal axis, and will return one of the constants listed below.

draw_get_lighting.name: draw_get_lighting
draw_get_lighting.description: This function will return whether lighting is enabled (`true`) or not (`false`) for the whole scene.

draw_get_swf_aa_level.name: draw_get_swf_aa_level
draw_get_swf_aa_level.description: This function can be used to get the anti-aliasing (AA) level for SWF format vector sprites. The return value will between 0 and 1 and shows how "smooth" the edges of these sprites will be drawn. You can set the AA level using the function `draw_set_swf_aa_level()`.

draw_get_valign.name: draw_get_valign
draw_get_valign.description: This function is used to get the text alignment setting along the vertical axis, and will return one of the constants listed below.

draw_getpixel.name: draw_getpixel

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the pixel to check
The y coordinate of the pixel to check

draw_getpixel.example:
```
draw_set_colour(draw_getpixel(500,200));
```
The above code will set the drawing colour for all text, forms and primitives to the colour of the pixel at (500,200) on the game screen.
draw_getpixel.description:
With this function you can get the colour value of any pixel that is being drawn to the current render target. This means that the results will depend on the event in which the function is called, and also on the target surface being used. Note that
    this will *not* return any alpha values, for that you should use `draw_getpixel_ext()`.

draw_getpixel_ext.name: draw_getpixel_ext

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the pixel to check
The y coordinate of the pixel to check

draw_getpixel_ext.example:
```
col = draw_getpixel_ext(mouse_x, mouse_y); alpha = (col >> 24) & 255; blue = (col >> 16) & 255; green = (col >> 8) & 255; red = col & 255;
```
The above code will get the 32bit colour value at the position of the mouse and then split it into its component values, storing them in variables.
draw_getpixel_ext.description:
With this function you can get the full **abgr 32bit** value of any pixel that is being drawn to the current render target. This means that the results will depend on the event in which the function is called, and also on the target surface being
    used.

draw_healthbar.name: draw_healthbar

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the healthbar
The y coordinate of the top of the healthbar
The x coordinate of the right of the healthbar
The y coordinate of the bottom of the healthbar
The variable which defines total health (between 0 and 100)
The colour of the background for the bar
The colour of the bar when at no health (0)
The colour of the bar when at full health (100)
Where the bar is "anchored" (0 = left, 1 = right, 2 = top, 3 = bottom)
Whether the bar's background is drawn (`true`) or not (`false`). If false, the backcol argument is disregarded.
Whether the bar's elements have a 1px wide black border (`true`) or not (`false`).

draw_healthbar.example:
```
var pc; pc = (hp / max_hp) * 100; draw_healthbar(100, 100, 500, 200, pc, c_black, c_red, c_lime, 0, true, true)
```
The above code uses the percentage value that you get from the variables "hp" and "hp_max" to draw a standard red/green healthbar.
draw_healthbar.description:
With this function you can draw a coloured bar to show a constant value. Although the function uses the word "healthbar" you can use this to display anything you wish as long as the amount to be displayed is a percentage value between 0 and
    100 (a percentage of any value can be calculated with the formula **(CURRENT_Value / MAXIMUM_value) * 100**), so, for example, you can use this to display power, health, mana, time or anything else that would benefit from a bar display.

draw_highscore.name: draw_highscore

parameters.description: The x coordinate of the left of the highscore rectangle.
The y coordinate of the top of the highscore rectangle.
The x coordinate of the right of the highscore rectangle.
The y coordinate of the bottom of the highscore rectangle.

draw_highscore.example:
```
draw_highscore(100, 100, room_width - 100, room_height - 100);
```
This would draw the highscore table in a rectangle in the middle of the room with a 100px border.
draw_highscore.description:
This simple function will draw the current list of internally stored high scores using the currently set font, colour and alpha values within the specified rectangle. You provide the coordinates for the upper left corner and lower right corner of the
    rectangular area to draw the text, and GameMaker Studio 2 will take care of the rest, with spacing and position being done automatically.

draw_light_define_ambient.name: draw_light_define_ambient

parameters.description: The colour to use (either a constant, a real or a hex value).

draw_light_define_ambient.example:
```
draw_light_define_ambient(c_white);
```
The above code will define the ambient lighting as being white.
draw_light_define_ambient.description:
This function is used to control the ambient light of a scene, which is the light that you have in a scene even without having defined any point or directional light sources. It is effectively the overall colour and brightness (or darkness) of a scene.
    The default colour is `c_black`.

draw_light_define_direction.name: draw_light_define_direction

parameters.description: The index number of the light (arbitrary)
The x component of the light vector
The y component of the light vector
The z component of the light vector
The colour to use for the light (either a constant, a real or a hex value).

draw_light_define_direction.example:
```
draw_set_lighting(true); draw_light_define_direction(1, 0, 1, 0, c_white); draw_light_enable(1, true);
```
The above code will enable lighting for the whole scene, then define a white directional light in the room space, and then finally turn that light on.
draw_light_define_direction.description:
This function is for defining a directional light, where the direction and intensity are set by the values input for the x, y and z unit vector (meaning that they must be between -1 and 1, where 1 or -1 is full intensity, and 0 is no intensity). The
